newsitem.title: KAZAKHSTAN: Kazakhs eye shinier future for ferro-alloys/chrome.
newsitem.headline: Kazakhs eye shinier future for ferro-alloys/chrome.

text.p: Kazakhstan's output of ferro-alloys, including those of chrome, could rise 10-15 percent this year if world metals prices become slightly more positive, the country's main ferro-alloy producer said on Tuesday.

"If international markets develop normally, Kazakhstan's output of ferro-alloys could rise by 10-15 percent this year," Yevgeny Maramygin, aide to the director of the Aksussky Ferro-alloy Plant, told Reuters from the northern town of Aksu.
The Aksussky plant is one of Kazakhstan's two producers of ferro-alloys and accounts for four-fifths of the former Soviet republic's alloys output.
Aksussky has already started up a new furnace with an annual processing capacity of 80,000 tonnes of chrome.
Maramygin told Reuters that by the end of this year or in the first quarter of 1998, the plant would install, with the help of Germany's Mannesmann AG, another $25 million furnace of equal capacity.
Aksussky is part of national chrome company TNK Kazkhrom, whose main shareholder is British Virgin islands-registered Japan Chrome Corporation, which owns a 55.2 percent stake.
Due to lower prices on international markets, Kazkhrom ended 1996 with losses of 126 million tenge after profits of 8.12 billion in the previous year.
Kazakhstan produced 548,800 tonnes of ferro-alloys last year, or 23.8 percent less than in 1995.
Ferro-alloys are important for the production of high-quality stainless and heatproof steels.
Maramygin said the main reason for Aksussky's troubles was a market glut last year.
"We simply could not sell our output, including ferro-chrome, and could only stock it," he said.
"But, anyway, we are becoming recognised on world markets -- and, besides, our chrome is the best quality in the world."
He said Kazakh chrome-alloys contained 65-69 percent chrome, while similar alloys offered by major competitors contained 52-55 percent chrome.
Kazakhstan's chrome ore reserves are estimated to be the second largest in the world, and Kazkhrom groups all of Kazakkstan's chrome mines and plants.
